content:
I'm puzzled by something, so this question is going to be rather vague - sort of like "what's going on here?"

But the phenomenon I'm asking about is precise enough.

First a summary. There's a standard way to get a chain complex from a globular vector space, but I seem to be getting one from something else, which I will temporarily called a 'coglobular vector space'. I don't like this, so I'd like to convert it to a globular vector space. I could do this by taking duals, but I don't really want to, because I'm afraid that will mess up other things.

Next let me give a detailed explanation.

Suppose I have vector spaces V2,V1,V0V_2, V_1, V_0V2​,V1​,V0​ and linear maps

s,t:V2→V1,s,t:V1→V0 s, t: V_2 \to V_1, \qquad s,t : V_1 \to V_0 s,t:V2​→V1​,s,t:V1​→V0​

This setup is an example of a globular vector space if

ss=st,ts=tt s s = s t, \qquad t s = t t ss=st,ts=tt

which is the usual identities obeyed by source and target maps in a 2-category. I'll call these the globular identities.

If I then define

d=s−t d = s - t d=s−t

then I get a chain complex because

d2=(s−t)(s−t)=s2−st−ts+t2=0 d^2 = (s - t)(s - t) = s^2 - st - ts + t^2 = 0 d2=(s−t)(s−t)=s2−st−ts+t2=0

where in the last step we use the globular identities.

But here's another way to get a chain complex! Suppose I have a vector space X XX with two subspaces V,W⊆XV, W \subseteq XV,W⊆X. I then get a subspace V∩WV \cap WV∩W, and two obvious inclusions

iV,iW:V∩W→V⊕W i_V, i_W : V \cap W \to V \oplus W iV​,iW​:V∩W→V⊕W

There are also two obvious quotient maps

pV,pW:V⊕W→X p_V, p_W : V \oplus W \to X pV​,pW​:V⊕W→X

The first maps (v,w)∈V⊕W(v,w) \in V \oplus W(v,w)∈V⊕W to v∈Vv \in Vv∈V regarded as an element of XXX. The second maps it to w∈Ww \in Ww∈W regarded as an element of XXX.

I can then define a chain complex

V∩W→dV⊕W→dX V \cap W \xrightarrow{d} V \oplus W \xrightarrow{d} X V∩Wd​V⊕Wd​X

where

  • d:V∩W→V⊕W d: V \cap W \to V \oplus W d:V∩W→V⊕W is given by iV+iWi_V + i_WiV​+iW​
  • d:V⊕W→X d: V \oplus W \to Xd:V⊕W→X is given by pV−pWp_V - p_W pV​−pW​

Why is d2=0d^2 = 0d2=0 this time? It's because we have

pViV=pWiV,pViW=pWiW p_V i_V = p_W i_V, \qquad p_V i_W = p_W i_WpV​iV​=pW​iV​,pV​iW​=pW​iW​

(Please check this, I find it so unnerving that I feel it could be wrong though it seems obviously correct!)

Using these identities we get

d2=(pV−pW)(iV+iW) d^2 = (p_V - p_W)(i_V + i_W) d2=(pV​−pW​)(iV​+iW​)
=pViV−pWiV+pViW−pWiW=0 = p_V i_V - p_W i_V + p_V i_W - p_W i_W = 0=pV​iV​−pW​iV​+pV​iW​−pW​iW​=0

Now, this second situation smells a lot like the first one. But these identities

pViV=pWiV,pViW=pWiWp_V i_V = p_W i_V, \qquad p_V i_W = p_W i_WpV​iV​=pW​iV​,pV​iW​=pW​iW​.

are not the globular identities, as far as I can tell. They're a special case of the co-globular identities, which are the globular identities in reverse:

ss=ts,st=tt s s = t s, \qquad s t = t tss=ts,st=tt.

So: what's going on here?
You have ddd is given by iV+iWi_V + i_WiV​+iW​ at one point, and then later d2=(pV−pW)(iV−iW)d^2 = (p_V - p_W)(i_V - i_W)d2=(pV​−pW​)(iV​−iW​). What's with the sign change?
Error, probably just a typo. Let me try to fix it.

Thanks, I think it's okay now!

By the way, the correct formula is supposed to be massively reminiscent of a certain bit of the Mayer-Vietoris exact sequence, and this sort of calculation is why the composite of two maps in that bit equals zero. So it's not something I cleverly made up.
Shouldn't it be pViV=pWiWp_V i_V = p_W i_WpV​iV​=pW​iW​ and pViW=0=pWiVp_V i_W = 0 = p_W i_VpV​iW​=0=pW​iV​?

John Baez said:

  • d:V∩W→V⊕W d: V \cap W \to V \oplus W d:V∩W→V⊕W is given by iV+iWi_V + i_WiV​+iW​
  • d:V⊕W→X d: V \oplus W \to Xd:V⊕W→X is given by pV−pWp_V - p_W pV​−pW​

Why is d2=0d^2 = 0d2=0 this time?

I think by your definition,

  • d:V∩W→V⊕Wd: V \cap W \to V \oplus W d:V∩W→V⊕W, x↦(x,0)+(0,x)=(x,x)x \mapsto (x,0) + (0,x)=(x,x)x↦(x,0)+(0,x)=(x,x), and

  • d:V⊕W→X d: V \oplus W \to Xd:V⊕W→X, (v,w)↦v−w(v,w) \mapsto v- w(v,w)↦v−w .

Hence, d2(x)=x−x=0d^{2}(x)=x - x=0d2(x)=x−x=0. So, it is a chain complex.

However, if I am not making any mistake, then, for x∈V∩Wx \in V \cap Wx∈V∩W, pViW(x)=pv(0,x)=0p_V i_{W}(x)=p_{v}(0,x)=0pV​iW​(x)=pv​(0,x)=0 but, pW∘iw(x)=pw(0,x)=xp_{W} \circ i_{w}(x)=p_{w}(0,x)=xpW​∘iw​(x)=pw​(0,x)=x. Hence, pViW≠pWiWp_{V} i_{W}\neq p_{W} i_{W}pV​iW​=pW​iW​, unless V∩W=0V \cap W=0V∩W=0. I think the same is true for the other identity.
I had assumed that iW:V∩W→V⊕Wi_W:V \cap W \to V \oplus WiW​:V∩W→V⊕W acted by x↦(x,x)x \mapsto (x,x)x↦(x,x). I might be wrong about that though! [EDIT: As clarified below, this is not correct.]

I wanted iW(x)=(0,x)i_W(x) = (0,x)iW​(x)=(0,x) - the symbol iWi_WiW​ was intended as short for "inclusion of V∩WV \cap WV∩W into the WWW summand". Similarly iV(x)=(x,0)i_V(x) = (x,0)iV​(x)=(x,0).

I just had a beer so I won't attempt to deal with Mike and Adittya's corrections now - if I didn't get something right before, there's no way I'll get it right now! But thanks, folks, for helping.

Mike Shulman said:

Shouldn't it be pViV=pWiWp_V i_V = p_W i_WpV​iV​=pW​iW​ and pViW=0=pWiVp_V i_W = 0 = p_W i_VpV​iW​=0=pW​iV​?

Yes, you're right! These are the same relations that hold for the inclusions and projections when you have the biproduct of VVV and WWW.

Somehow I convinced myself that very different relations hold when we have subspaces V,W⊆XV , W \subseteq XV,W⊆X and

iV:V∩W→V⊕W,iV(x)=(x,0) i_V: V \cap W \to V \oplus W , \qquad i_V(x) = (x,0)iV​:V∩W→V⊕W,iV​(x)=(x,0)
iW:V∩W→V⊕W,iW(x)=(0,x) i_W: V \cap W \to V \oplus W, \qquad i_W(x) = (0,x) iW​:V∩W→V⊕W,iW​(x)=(0,x)

pV:V⊕W→X,pV(v,w)=v p_V: V \oplus W \to X , \qquad p_V(v,w) = v pV​:V⊕W→X,pV​(v,w)=v
pW:V⊕W→X,pW(v,w)=w p_W: V \oplus W \to X, \qquad p_W(v,w) = w pW​:V⊕W→X,pW​(v,w)=w

but in fact the same relations hold.

You mentioned the Mayer-Vietoris sequence, so you probably know that this construction is pretty standard, but maybe it would be helpful to mention that more generally it's also a standard thing in triangulated category theory (and stable ∞\infty∞-category theory), to make a distinguished triangle (= fiber sequence = cofiber sequence) from a homotopy pullback square (= homotopy pushout square)

Thanks. I've always been scared of triangulated category (though slightly less so when the management informed me it was secretly stable ∞\infty∞-category theory). So I didn't know this.

I was just hoping that all the chain complexes I need to work with in my project arise from globular objects via the d=s−td = s - td=s−t construction. So far it ain't looking good.
